where ''D'' is the degree of precision, ''a'' and ''b'' are the Taylor's law coefficients, ''n'' is the sample size and ''T'' is the total number of individuals sampled.
Serra ''et al'' have proposed a stopping rule based on Taylor's law.<ref name=Serraa2012>Serraa GV, La Porta NC, Avalos S, Mazzuferi V (2012) Fixed-precision sequential sampling plans for estimating alfalfa caterpillar, ''Colias lesbia'', egg density in alfalfa, ''Medicago sativa'', fields in Córdoba, Argentina. J Insect Sci 13: 41</ref>
<math> T_n \ge \left( \frac{ a n^{ 1 - b } }{ D^2 } \right)^{ \frac{ 1 } { 2 - b } } </math>
where ''a'' and ''b'' are the parameters from Taylor's law, ''D'' is the desired level of precision and ''T''<sub>n</sub> is the total sample size.
Serra ''et al'' also proposed a second stopping rule based on Iwoa's regression
<math> T_n \ge \frac{ \alpha - 1 }{ D^2 - \frac{ \beta - 1 }{ n } }</math>
where ''α'' and ''β'' are the parameters of the regression line, ''D'' is the desired level of precision and ''T''<sub>n</sub> is the total sample size.
The authors recommended that ''D'' be set at 0.1 for studies of population dynamics and ''D'' = 0.25 for pest control.
==Related analyses==
It is considered to be good practice to estimate at least one additional analysis of aggregation (other than Taylor's law) because the use of only a single index may be misleading.<ref name=Myers1978>Myers JH (1978). Selecting a measure of dispersion. Environ Entomol 7: 619–621</ref> Although a number of other methods for detecting relationships between the variance and mean in biological samples have been proposed, to date none have achieved the popularity of Taylor's law. The most popular analysis used in conjunction with Taylor's law is probably Iowa's Patchiness regression test but all the methods listed here have been used in the literature.
===Barlett–Iawo model===
Barlett in 1936<ref name=Bartlett1936 /> and later Iawo independently in 1968<ref name=Iwao1968a>Iwao S (1968) A new regression method for analyzing the aggregation pattern of animal populations. Res Popul Ecol 10: 1–20</ref> both proposed an alternative relationship between the variance and the mean. In symbols
: <math> s_i^2 = am_i + bm_i^2 \, </math>
where ''s'' is the variance in the ''i''th sample and ''m''<sub>''i''</sub> is the mean of the ''i''th sample
When the population follows a [[negative binomial distribution]], ''a'' = 1 and ''b'' = ''k'' (the exponent of the negative binomial distribution).
This alternative formulation has not been found to be as good a fit as Taylor's law in most studies.
===Nachman model===
Nachman proposed a relationship between the mean density and the proportion of samples with zero counts:<ref name=Nachman1981>Nachman G (1981) A mathematical model of the functional relationship between density and spatial distribution of a population. J Anim Ecol 50: 453–460</ref>
: <math> p_0 = \exp( -a m^b ) </math>
where ''p''<sub>0</sub> is the proportion of the sample with zero counts, ''m'' is the mean density, ''a'' is a scale parameter and ''b'' is a dispersion parameter. If ''a'' = ''b'' = 0 the distribution is random. This relationship is usually tested in its logarithmic form
: <math> \log m = c + d \log p_0 </math>
Allsop used this relationship along with Taylor's law to derive an expression for the proportion of infested units in a sample<ref name=Allsopp1991>Allsopp PG (1991) Binomial sequential sampling of adult ''Saccharicoccus sacchari'' on sugarcane. Entomologia Experimentalis et Applicata 60 (3) 213–218</ref>
: <math> P_1 = 1 - \exp\left( -\exp\left( \frac{ \frac{ \log_e \left( \frac{ A^2 } a \right) }{ b - 2 } + \log_e( n )\left( \frac{ b - 1 }{ b - 2 } - 1 \right) - c } d \right) \right)</math>
: <math> N = n P_1 </math>
where
: <math> A^2 = \frac{D^2}{z^2_{\alpha/2}} </math>
where ''D''<sup>2</sup> is the degree of precision desired, ''z''<sub>α/2</sub> is the upper α/2 of the normal distribution, ''a'' and ''b'' are the Taylor's law coefficients, ''c'' and ''d'' are the Nachman coefficients, ''n'' is the sample size and ''N'' is the number of infested units.
===Kono–Sugino equation===
Binary sampling is not uncommonly used in ecology. In 1958 Kono and Sugino derived an equation that relates the proportion of samples without individuals to the mean density of the samples.<ref name=Kono1958>Kono T & Sugino T (1958) On the estimation of density of rice stem infested by the rice stem borer. Japanese J Appl Entomol and Zool 2: 184</ref>
: <math> \log( m ) = \log( a ) + b \log( - \log( p_0 ) ) </math>
where ''p''<sub>0</sub> is the proportion of the sample with no individuals, ''m'' is the mean sample density, ''a'' and ''b'' are constants. Like Taylor's law this equation has been found to fit a variety of populations including ones that obey Taylor's law. Unlike the negative binomial distribution this model is independent of the mean density.
The derivation of this equation is straightforward. Let the proportion of empty units be ''p''<sub>0</sub> and assume that these are distributed exponentially. Then
<math> p_0 = \exp( -A m^B ) </math>
Taking logs twice and re arranging, we obtain the equation above. This model is the same as that proposed by Nachman.
The advantage of this model is that it does not require counting the individuals but rather their presence or absence. Counting individuals may not be possible in many cases particularly where insects are the matter of study.
;Note
The equation was derived while examining the relationship between the proportion ''P'' of a series of rice hills infested and the mean severity of infestation ''m''. The model studied was
: <math> P = 1 - a e^{ b m } </math>
where ''a'' and ''b'' are empirical constants. Based on this model the constants ''a'' and ''b'' were derived and a table prepared relating the values of ''P'' and ''m''
;Uses
The predicted estimates of ''m'' from this equation are subject to bias<ref name=Binns1990>Binns MR & Bostonian NJ (1990) Robustness in empirically based binomial decision rules for integrated pest management. J Econ Entomol 83: 420–442</ref> and it is recommended that the adjusted mean ( ''m''<sub>a</sub> ) be used instead<ref name=Nachman1984>Nachman G (1984) Estimates of mean population density and spatial distribution of ''Tetranychus urticae'' (Acarina: Tetranychidae) and ''Phytoseiulus persimilis'' (Acarina: Phytoseiidae) based upon the proportion of empty sampling units. ''J Appl Ecolog'' 21: 903-991</ref>
: <math> m_a = m \left( 1 - \frac { \operatorname{var}( \log( m_i ) ) } 2 \right) </math>
where var is the variance of the sample unit means ''m''<sub>''i''</sub> and ''m'' is the overall mean.
An alternative adjustment to the mean estimates is<ref name=Nachman1984/> : <math> m_a = m e^{ ( \text{MSE} / 2 ) } </math>
where MSE is the mean square error of the regression.
This model may also be used to estimate stop lines for enumerative (sequential) sampling. The variance of the estimated means is<ref name=Schaalje1991>Schaalje GB, Butts RA, Lysyk TL (1991) Simulation studies of binomial sampling: a new variance estimator and density pre&ctor, with special reference to the Russian wheat aphid (Homoptera: Aphididae). J Econ Entomol 84: 140–147</ref>
: <math> \operatorname{var}( m ) = m^2 ( c_1 + c_2 - c_3 + MSE ) </math>
where
: <math> c_1 = \frac{ \beta^2 ( 1 - p_0 ) }{ n p_0 \log_e( p_0 )^2 } </math>
: <math> c_2 = \frac{ \text{MSE} } { N } + s_{\beta}^2 ( \log_e( \log_e( p_0 ) ) - p^2 ) </math>
: <math> c_3 = \frac{ \exp( a + ( b - 2 )[\alpha - \beta \log_e( p_0 ) ] ) } n </math>
where MSE is the [[mean square error]] of the regression, ''α'' and ''β'' are the constant and slope of the regression respectively, ''s''<sub>β</sub><sup>2</sup> is the variance of the slope of the regression, ''N'' is the number of points in the regression, ''n'' is the number of sample units and ''p'' is the mean value of ''p''<sub>0</sub> in the regression. The parameters ''a'' and ''b'' are estimated from Taylor's law:
: <math> s^2 = a + b \log_e( m ) </math>
===Hughes–Madden equation===
Hughes and Madden have proposed testing a similar relationship applicable to binary observations in cluster, where each cluster contains from 0 to n individuals.<ref name="Hughes&Madden1992"/>
: <math> var_\text{obs} = a p^b ( 1 - p )^c </math>
where ''a'', ''b'' and ''c'' are constants, ''var<sub>obs</sub>'' is the observed variance, and p is the proportion of individuals with a trait (such as disease), an estimate of the probability of an individual with a trait. In logarithmic form, this relationship is
: <math> \log( \operatorname{var}_\text{obs} ) = \log( a ) + b \log( p ) + c \log( 1 - p ) .</math>
In most cases, it is assumed that ''b = c'', leading to a simple model
: <math> \operatorname{var}_\text{obs} = a ( p( 1 - p ) )^b </math>
This relationship has been subjected to less extensive testing than Taylor's law. However, it has accurately described over 100 data sets, and there are no published examples reporting that it does not works.<ref name="Turechek et al.2011"/>
A variant of this equation was proposed by Shiyomi et al. (<ref name=Shiyomi1998>Shiyomi M, Egawa T, Yamamoto Y (1998) Negative hypergeometric series and Taylor's power law in occurrence of plant populations in semi-natural grassland in Japan. Proceedings of the 18th International Grassland Congress on grassland management. The Inner Mongolia Univ Press pp 35–43 (1998)</ref>) who suggested testing the regression
: <math> \log( \operatorname{var}_\text{obs} / n^2 ) = a + b \log( p ( 1 - p ) / n ) </math>
where var<sub>obs</sub> is the variance, ''a'' and ''b'' are the constants of the regression, ''n'' here is the sample size (not sample per cluster) and ''p'' is the probability of a sample containing at least one individual.
===Negative binomial distribution model===
A negative binomial model has also been proposed.<ref name=Wilson1983>Wilson L T & Room PM (1983) Clumping patterns of fruit and arthropods in cotton, with implications for binomial sampling. Environ Entomol 12: 50–54</ref> The dispersion parameter (''k'') using the method of moments is ''m''<sup>2</sup> / ( ''s''<sup>2</sup> – ''m'' ) and ''p''<sub>''i''</sub> is the proportion of samples with counts > 0. The ''s''<sup>2</sup> used in the calculation of ''k'' are the values predicted by Taylor's law. ''p''<sub>''i''</sub> is plotted against 1 - ( ''k'' ( ''k'' + ''m'' ) <sup>−1</sup> )<sup>''k''</sup> and the fit of the data is visually inspected.
Perry and Taylor have proposed an alternative estimator of ''k'' based on Taylor's law.<ref name=Perry1986>Perry JN & Taylor LR(1986). Stability of real interacting populations in space and time: implications, alternatives and negative binomial. J Animal Ecol 55: 1053–1068</ref>
: <math> 1/k = am^{ b - 2 } - 1 / m</math>
A better estimate of the dispersion parameter can be made with the method of [[maximum likelihood]]. For the negative binomial it can be estimated from the equation<ref name="Bliss1953"/>
: <math> \sum \frac { A_x } { k + x } = N \log( 1 + m / k ) </math>
where ''A''<sub>''x''</sub> is the total number of samples with more than ''x'' individuals, ''N'' is the total number of individuals, ''x'' is the number of individuals in a sample, ''m'' is the mean number of individuals per sample and ''k'' is the exponent. The value of ''k'' has to be estimated numerically.
Goodness of fit of this model can be tested in a number of ways including using the chi square test. As these may be biased by small samples an alternative is the ''U'' statistic – the difference between the variance expected under the negative binomial distribution and that of the sample. The expected variance of this distribution is ''m'' + ''m''<sup>2</sup> / ''k'' and
: <math> U = s^2 - m + m^2 / k </math>
where ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the sample variance, ''m'' is the sample mean and ''k'' is the negative binomial parameter.
The variance of U is<ref name="Bliss1953"/>
: <math> \operatorname{var}( U ) = 2m p^2 q \left( \frac { 1 - R^2 } {-\log( 1 - R ) - R } \right) + p^4 \frac { (1 - R)^{-k} - 1 - kR } { N ( -\log( 1 - R ) - R)^2 } </math>
where ''p'' = ''m'' / ''k'', ''q'' = 1 + ''p'', ''R'' = ''p'' / ''q'' and ''N'' is the total number of individuals in the sample. The expected value of ''U'' is 0. For large sample sizes ''U'' is distributed normally.
Note: The negative binomial is actually a family of distributions defined by the relation of the mean to the variance
<math> \sigma^2 = \mu + a \mu^p </math>
where ''a'' and ''p'' are constants. When ''a'' = 0 this defines the Poisson distribution. With ''p'' = 1 and ''p'' = 2, the distribution is known as the NB1 and NB2 distribution respectively.
This model is a version of that proposed earlier by Barlett.
===Tests for a common dispersion parameter===
The dispersion parameter (''k'')<ref name="Bliss1953"/> is
: <math> k = m^2 / ( s^2 - m ) </math>
where ''m'' is the sample mean and ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance. If ''k''<sup>−1</sup> is > 0 the population is considered to be aggregated; ''k''<sup>−1</sup> = 0 the population is considered to be random; and if ''k''<sup>−1</sup> is < 0 the population is considered to be uniformly distributed.
Southwood has recommended regressing ''k'' against the mean and a constant<ref name=Southwood1978 />
: <math> k_i = a + b m_i </math>
where ''k''<sub>''i''</sub> and ''m''<sub>''i''</sub> are the dispersion parameter and the mean of the ith sample respectively to test for the existence of a common dispersion parameter (''k''<sub>''c''</sub>). A slope (''b'') value significantly > 0 indicates the dependence of ''k'' on the mean density.
An alternative method was proposed by Elliot who suggested plotting ( ''s''<sup>2</sup> − ''m'' ) against ( ''m''<sup>2</sup> − ''s''<sup>2</sup> / ''n'' ).<ref name=Elliot1977a>Elliot JM (1977) Some methods for the statistical analysis of samples of benthic invertebrates. 2nd ed. Freshwater Biological Association, Cambridge, United Kingdom</ref> ''k''<sub>''c''</sub> is equal to 1/slope of this regression.
===Charlier coefficient===
This coefficient (''C'') is defined as
<math> C = \frac{ 100 ( s^2 - m )^{0.5} } { m } </math>
If the population can be assumed to be distributed in a negative binomial fashion, then ''C'' = 100 (1/''k'')<sup>0.5</sup> where ''k'' is the dispersion parameter of the distribution.
===Cole's index of dispersion===
This index (''I''<sub>c</sub>) is defined as<ref name=Cole1946>Cole LC (1946) A theory for analyzing contagiously distributed populations. Ecol 27: 329–341</ref>
: <math> I_c = \frac{ \Sigma x^2 }{ ( \Sigma x )^2 } </math>
The usual interpretation of this index is as follows: values of ''I''<sub>c</sub> < 1, 1, > 1 are taken to mean a uniform distribution, a random distribution or an aggregated distribution.
Because ''s''<sup>2</sup> = Σ x<sup>2</sup> − (Σx)<sup>2</sup>, the index can also be written
: <math> I_c = \frac{ s^2 + ( nm )^2 }{ ( nm )^2 } = \frac{ 1 }{ n^2} \frac{ s^2 }{ m^2 } + 1 </math>
If Taylor's law can be assumed to hold, then
: <math> I_c = \frac{ a m^{ b - 2 } }{ n^2 } + 1 </math>
===Lloyd's indexes===
Lloyd's index of mean crowding (''IMC'') is the average number of other points contained in the sample unit that contains a randomly chosen point.<ref name=Lloyd1967>Lloyd M (1967) Mean crowding. J Anim Ecol 36: 1–30</ref>
: <math> \mathrm{ IMC } = m + s^2 / m - 1 </math>
where ''m'' is the sample mean and ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance.
Lloyd's index of patchiness (''IP'')<ref name="Lloyd1967"/> is
: <math> \mathrm{ IP } = \text{IMC} / m </math>
It is a measure of pattern intensity that is unaffected by thinning (random removal of points). This index was also proposed by Pielou in 1988 and is sometimes known by this name also.
Because an estimate of the variance of ''IP'' is extremely difficult to estimate from the formula itself, LLyod suggested fitting a negative binomial distribution to the data. This method gives a parameter ''k''
: <math> s^2 = m + \frac{ m^2 }{ k } </math>
Then
: <math> SE( IP ) = \frac{ 1 }{ k^2 } [ \operatorname{var}( k ) + \frac{ k ( k + 1 ) ( k + m ) }{ mq } ] </math>
where ''SE''(''IP'') is the standard error of the index of patchiness,''var''(''k'') is the variance of the parameter ''k'' and ''q'' is the number of [[quadrat]]s sampled..
If the population obeys Taylor's law then
: <math> \mathrm{ IMC } = m + a^{ -1 } m^{ 1 - b } - 1 </math>
: <math> \mathrm{ IP } = 1 + a^{ -1 } m^{ - b } - \frac { 1 } { m } </math>
===Patchiness regression test===
Iwao proposed a patchiness regression to test for clumping<ref name=Iwao1968b>Iwao S & Kuno E (1968) Use of the regression of mean crowding on mean density for estimating sample size and the transformation of data for the analysis of variance. Res Pop Ecology, 10, 210–214</ref><ref name=Ifoulis2006>Ifoulis AA, Savopoulou-Soultani M (2006) Developing optimum sample size and multistage sampling plans for ''Lobesia botrana'' (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae) larval infestation and injury in northern Greece. J Econ Entomol 99(5):1890–1898</ref>
Let
: <math> y_i = m_i + s^2 / m_i - 1 </math>
''y''<sub>''i''</sub> here is Lloyd's index of mean crowding.<ref name="Lloyd1967"/> Perform an ordinary least squares regression of ''m''<sub>''i''</sub> against ''y''.
In this regression the value of the slope (''b'') is an indicator of clumping: the slope = 1 if the data is Poisson-distributed. The constant (''a'') is the number of individuals that share a unit of habitat at infinitesimal density and may be < 0, 0 or > 0. These values represent regularity, randomness and aggregation of populations in spatial patterns respectively. A value of ''a'' < 1 is taken to mean that the basic unit of the distribution is a single individual.
Where the statistic ''s''<sup>2</sup> / ''m'' is not constant it has been recommended to use instead to regress Lloyd's index against ''am'' + ''bm''<sup>2</sup> where ''a'' and ''b'' are constants.<ref name=Ho1993>Ho CC (1993) Dispersion statistics and sample size estimates for ''Tetranychus kanzawai'' (Acari: Tetranychidae) on mulberry. Environ Entomol 22: 21–25</ref>
The sample size (''n'') for a given degree of precision (''D'') for this regression is given by<ref name="Ho1993"/>
: <math> n = \left( \frac{ t }{ D } \right)^2 ( \frac{ a + 1 } { m } + b - 1 )</math>
where ''a'' is the constant in this regression, ''b'' is the slope, ''m'' is the mean and ''t'' is the critical value of the t distribution.
Iawo has proposed a sequential sampling test based on this regression.<ref name=Iwao1975>Iwao S (1975) A new method of sequential sampling to classify populations relative to a critical density. Res Popul Ecol 16: 281–28</ref> The upper and lower limits of this test are based on critical densities m<sub>c</sub> where control of a pest requires action to be taken.
: <math> N_u = im_c + t( i ( a + 1 ) m_c + ( b - 1 ) m_c^2 )^{ 1 / 2 } </math>
: <math> N_l = im_c - t( i ( a + 1 ) m_c + ( b - 1 ) m_c^2 )^{ 1 / 2 } </math>
where ''N''<sub>''u''</sub> and ''N''<sub>''l''</sub> are the upper and lower bounds respectively, ''a'' is the constant from the regression, ''b'' is the slope and ''i'' is the number of samples.
Kuno has proposed an alternative sequential stopping test also based on this regression.<ref name=Kuno1969>Kuno E (1969) A new method of sequential sampling to obtain the population estimates with a fixed level of precision. Res. Pooul. Ecol 11: 127–136</ref>
: <math> T_n = \frac { a + 1 } { D^2 - \frac { b - 1 } n } </math>
where ''T''<sub>''n''</sub> is the total sample size, ''D'' is the degree of precision, ''n'' is the number of samples units, a is the constant and b is the slope from the regression respectively.
Kuno's test is subject to the condition that ''n'' ≥ (''b'' − 1) / ''D''<sup>2</sup>
Parrella and Jones have proposed an alternative but related stop line<ref>Parrella MP, Jones VP (1985) Yellow traps as monitoring tools for ''Liriomyza trifolii'' (Diptera: Agromyzidae) in chrysanthemum greenhouses. J Econ Entomol 78, 53-56</ref>
: <math> T_n = \left( 1 - \frac { n } { N } \right) \frac { a + 1 } { D^2 - \left( 1 - \frac { n } { N } \right) \frac { b - 1 } { n } } </math>
where ''a'' and ''b'' are the parameters from the regression, ''N'' is the maximum number of sampled units and ''n'' is the individual sample size.
===Morisita’s index of dispersion===
Morisita's index of dispersion ( ''I''<sub>''m''</sub> ) is the scaled probability that two points chosen at random from the whole population are in the same sample.<ref name=Morisita1959>Morisita M (1959) Measuring the dispersion and the analysis of distribution patterns. Memoires of the Faculty of Science, Kyushu University Series E. Biol 2:215–235</ref> Higher values indicate a more clumped distribution.
: <math> I_m = \frac { \sum x ( x - 1 ) } { n m ( m - 1 ) } </math>
An alternative formulation is
: <math> I_m = n \frac{ \sum x^2 - \sum x } { ( \sum x )^2 - \sum x } </math>
where ''n'' is the total sample size, ''m'' is the sample mean and ''x'' are the individual values with the sum taken over the whole sample. It is also equal to
: <math> I_m = \frac { n IMC } { ( nm - 1 ) } </math>
where ''IMC'' is Lloyd's index of crowding.<ref name="Lloyd1967"/>
This index is relatively independent of the population density but is affected by the sample size. Values > 1 indicate clumping; values < 1 indicate a uniformity of distribution and a value of 1 indicates a random sample.
Morisita showed that the statistic<ref name="Morisita1959"/>
: <math> I_m ( \sum x - 1 ) + n - \sum x </math>
is distributed as a chi squared variable with ''n'' − 1 degrees of freedom.
An alternative significance test for this index has been developed for large samples.<ref name=Pedigo1994>Pedigo LP & Buntin GD (1994) Handbook of sampling methods for arthropods in agriculture. CRC Boca Raton FL</ref>
: <math> z = \frac { I_m - 1 } { ( 2 / n m^2 ) } </math>
where ''m'' is the overall sample mean, ''n'' is the number of sample units and ''z'' is the normal distribution [[abscissa]]. Significance is tested by comparing the value of ''z'' against the values of the [[normal distribution]].
A function for its calculation is available in the statistical [[R language]]. [http://cc.oulu.fi/~jarioksa/softhelp/vegan/html/dispindmorisita.html R function]
===Standardised Morisita’s index===
Smith-Gill developed a statistic based on Morisita's index which is independent of both sample size and population density and bounded by −1 and +1. This statistic is calculated as follows<ref name=Smith-Gill1975>Smith-Gill SJ (1975) Cytophysiological basis of disruptive pigmentary patterns in the leopard frog ''Rana pipiens''. II. Wild type and mutant cell specific patterns. J Morphol 146, 35–54</ref>
First determine Morisita's index ( ''I''<sub>''d''</sub> ) in the usual fashion. Then let ''k'' be the number of units the population was sampled from. Calculate the two critical values
: <math> M_u = \frac { \chi^2_{ 0.975 } - k + \sum x } { \sum x - 1 } </math>
: <math> M_c = \frac { \chi^2_{ 0.025 } - k + \sum x } { \sum x - 1 } </math>
where χ<sup>2</sup> is the chi square value for ''n'' − 1 degrees of freedom at the 97.5% and 2.5% levels of confidence.
The standardised index ( ''I''<sub>''p''</sub> ) is then calculated from one of the formulae below
When ''I''<sub>''d''</sub> ≥ ''M''<sub>''c''</sub> > 1
: <math> I_p = 0.5 + 0.5 ( \frac { I_d - M_c } { k - M_c } ) </math>
When ''M''<sub>''c''</sub> > ''I''<sub>''d''</sub> ≥ 1
: <math> I_p = 0.5 ( \frac { I_d - 1 } { M_u - 1 } ) </math>
When 1 > ''I''<sub>''d''</sub> ≥ ''M''<sub>''u''</sub>
: <math> I_p = -0.5 ( \frac { I_d - 1 } { M_u - 1 } ) </math>
When 1 > ''M''<sub>''u''</sub> > ''I''<sub>''d''</sub>
: <math> I_p = -0.5 + 0.5 ( \frac { I_d - M_u } { M_u } ) </math>
''I''<sub>''p''</sub> ranges between +1 and −1 with 95% confidence intervals of ±0.5. ''I''<sub>''p''</sub> has the value of 0 if the pattern is random; if the pattern is uniform, ''I''<sub>''p''</sub> < 0 and if the pattern shows aggregation, ''I''<sub>''p''</sub> > 0.
===Southwood's index of spatial aggregation===
Southwood's index of spatial aggregation (''k'') is defined as
: <math> \frac {1}{k} = \frac{m^*}{m} - 1 </math>
where ''m'' is the mean of the sample and ''m''* is Lloyd's index of crowding.<ref name=Southwood1978 />
===Fisher's index of dispersion===
Fisher's [[index of dispersion]]<ref name=Elliot1977b>Elliot JM (1977) Statistical analysis of samples of benthic invertebrates. Freshwater Biological Association. Ambleside</ref><ref name=Fisher1925>Fisher RA (1925) Statistical methods for research workers. Hafner, New York</ref> is
: <math> \mathrm{ID} = \frac{( n - 1 ) s^2 }{ m } </math>
This index may be used to test for over dispersion of the population. It is recommended that in applications n > 5<ref name=Hoel1943>Hoel P (1943) On the indices of dispersion. Ann Math Statist 14: 155</ref> and that the sample total divided by the number of samples is > 3. In symbols
: <math> \frac { \sum x } { n } > 3 </math>
where ''x'' is an individual sample value. The expectation of the index is equal to ''n'' and it is distributed as the [[chi-square distribution]] with ''n'' − 1 degrees of freedom when the population is Poisson distributed.<ref name=Hoel1943 /> It is equal to the scale parameter when the population obeys the [[gamma distribution]].
It can be applied both to the overall population and to the individual areas sampled individually. The use of this test on the individual sample areas should also include the use of a Bonferroni correction factor.
If the population obeys Taylor's law then
: <math> \mathrm{ ID } = ( n - 1 ) a m^{ b - 1 } </math>
===Index of cluster size===
The index of cluster size (''ICS'') was created by David and Moore.<ref name=David1954>David FN & Moore PG (1954) Notes on contagious distributions in plant populations. Ann Bot of London 18:47-53</ref> Under a random (Poisson) distribution ''ICS'' is expected to equal 0. Positive values indicate a clumped distribution; negative values indicate a uniform distribution.
: <math> \mathrm{ ICS } = s^2 / m - 1 </math>
where ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance and ''m'' is the mean.
If the population obeys Taylor's law
: <math> \mathrm{ ICS } = a m^{ b - 1 } - 1 </math>
The ''ICS'' is also equal to Katz's test statistic divided by ( ''n'' / 2 )<sup>1/2</sup> where ''n'' is the sample size. It is also related to Clapham's test statistic. It is also sometimes referred to as the clumping index.
===Green’s index===
Green's index (''GI'') is a modification of the index of cluster size that is independent of ''n'' the number of sample units.<ref name=Green1966>Green RH (1966) Measurement of non-randomness in spatial distributions. Res Pop Ecol 8:1-7</ref>
: <math> C_x = \frac { s^2 / m - 1 } { nm - 1 } </math>
This index equals 0 if the distribution is random, 1 if it is maximally aggregated and −1 / ( ''nm'' − 1 ) if it is uniform.
The distribution of Green's index is not currently known so statistical tests have been difficult to devise for it.
If the population obeys Taylor's law
: <math> C_x = \frac { a m^{ b - 1 } - 1 } { ( nm - 1 ) }</math>
===Binary dispersal index===
Binary sampling (presence/absence) is frequently used where it is difficult to obtain accurate counts. The dispersal index (''D'') is used when the study population is divided into a series of equal samples ( number of units = ''N'': number of units per sample = ''n'': total population size = ''n'' x ''N'' ).<ref name=Gottwald2007>Gottwald TR, Bassanezi RB, Amorim L, Bergamin-Filho A (2007) Spatial pattern analysis of citrus canker-infected plantings in São Paulo, Brazil, and augmentation of infection elicited by the Asian leafminer. Phytopathology 97(6):674–683</ref> The theoretical variance of a sample from a population with a binomial distribution is
: <math> s^2 = n p ( 1 - p ) </math>
where ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance, ''n'' is the number of units sampled and ''p'' is the mean proportion of sampling units with at least one individual present. The dispersal index (''D'') is defined as the ratio of observed variance to the expected variance. In symbols
: <math> D = \frac {var_{ obs } } { var_{ bin } } = \frac{ s^2 } { n p ( 1 - p ) }</math>
where ''var''<sub>''obs''</sub> is the observed variance and ''var''<sub>''bin''</sub> is the expected variance. The expected variance is calculated with the overall mean of the population. Values of ''D'' > 1 are considered to suggest aggregation. ''D''( ''n'' − 1 ) is distributed as the chi squared variable with ''n'' - 1 degrees of freedom where ''n'' is the number of units sampled.
An alternative test is the ''C'' test.<ref name=Hughes1993>Hughes G & Madden LV (1993) Using the beta-binomial distribution to describe aggregated patterns of disease incidence. Phytopathology 83:759−763</ref>
: <math> C = \frac { D( n N - 1 ) - n N } { ( 2 N ( n^2 - n ) ) ^{ 1 / 2 } } </math>
where ''D'' is the dispersal index, ''n'' is the number of units per sample and ''N'' is the number of samples. C is distributed normally. A statistically significant value of C indicates [[overdispersion]] of the population.
''D'' is also related to [[intraclass correlation]] ( ρ ) which is defined as<ref name=Fleiss1981>Fleiss JL (1981) Statistical methods for rates and proportions. 2nd ed. Wiley, Newy York, USA</ref>
: <math> \rho = 1 - \frac{ \sum x_i ( T - x_i ) } { p ( 1 - p ) N T ( T - 1 ) } </math>
where ''T'' is the number of organisms per sample, ''p'' is the likelihood of the organism having the sought after property (diseased, pest free, ''etc''), and x<sub>i</sub> is the number of organism in the ''i''th unit with this property. ''T'' must be the same for all sampled units. In this case with ''n'' constant
: <math> \rho = \frac{ D - 1 } { n - 1 } </math>
If the data can be fitted with a [[beta-binomial distribution]] then<ref name="Fleiss1981"/>
: <math> D = 1 + \frac{ ( n - 1 ) \theta }{ 1 + \theta } </math>
where ''θ'' is the parameter of the distribution.<ref name=Hughes1993 />
===Ma's population aggregation critical density===
Ma has proposed a parameter (''m''<sub>0</sub>) − the population aggregation critical density - to relate population density to Taylor's law.<ref name=Ma1991>Ma ZS (1991) Further interpreted Taylor’s Power Law and population aggregation critical density. Trans Ecol Soc China (1991) 284–288</ref>
: <math> m_0 = \exp( \frac{ \log ( a ) }{ 1 - b } ) </math>
==Related statistics==
A number of statistical tests are known that may be of use in applications.
===de Oliveria's statistic===
A related statistic suggested by de Oliveria<ref name=deOliveria1965>de Oliveria T (1965) Some elementary tests for mixtures of discrete distributions, ''in'' Patil, GP ''ed.'', Classical and contagious discrete distributions. Calcutá, Calcutta Publishing Society pp379-384</ref> is the difference of the variance and the mean.<ref name=Bohning1994>Bohning D (1994) A note on a test for Poisson overdispersion. Biometrica 81(2) 418-419</ref> If the population is Poisson distributed then
: <math> var( s^2 - m ) = \frac{ 2t^2 } { n - 1 } </math>
where ''t'' is the Poisson parameter, ''s''<sup>2</sup> is the variance, ''m'' is the mean and ''n'' is the sample size. The expected value of ''s''<sup>2</sup> - ''m'' is zero. This statistic is distributed normally.<ref name=Ping1995>Ping S (1995) Further study on the statistical test to detect spatial pattern. Biometrical J 37(2) 199–203</ref>
If the Poisson parameter in this equation is estimated by putting ''t'' = ''m'', after a little manipulation this statistic can be written
: <math> O_T = \sqrt { \frac { n - 1 } { 2 } } \frac { s^2 - m } { m } </math>
This is almost identical to Katz's statistic with ( ''n'' - 1 ) replacing ''n''. Again ''O''<sub>''T''</sub> is normally distributed with mean 0 and unit variance for large ''n''. This statistic is the same as the Neyman-Scott statistic.
;Note
de Oliveria actually suggested that the variance of ''s''<sup>2</sup> - ''m'' was ( 1 - 2''t''<sup>1/2</sup> + 3''t'' ) / ''n'' where ''t'' is the Poisson parameter. He suggested that ''t'' could be estimated by putting it equal to the mean (''m'') of the sample. Further investigation by Bohning<ref name="Bohning1994"/> showed that this estimate of the variance was incorrect. Bohning's correction is given in the equations above.
===Clapham's test===
In 1936 Clapham proposed using the ratio of the variance to the mean as a test statistic (the relative variance).<ref name=Clapham1936>Clapham AR (1936) Overdispersion in grassland communities and the use of statistical methods in plant ecology. J Ecol 14: 232</ref> In symbols
: <math> \theta = \frac{ s^2 }{ m } </math>
For a Possion distribution this ratio equals 1. To test for deviations from this value he proposed testing its value against the chi square distribution with ''n'' degrees of freedom where ''n'' is the number of sample units. The distribution of this statistic was studied further by Blackman<ref name=Blackman1942>Blackman GE (1942) Statistical and ecological studies on the distribution of species in plant communities. I. Dispersion as a factor in the study of changes in plant populations. Ann Bot N.s. vi: 351</ref> who noted that it was approximately normally distributed with a mean of 1 and a variance ( ''V''<sub>θ</sub> ) of
: <math> V_{ \theta } = \frac{ 2n } { ( n - 1 )^2 } </math>
The derivation of the variance was re analysed by Bartlett<ref name=Greig-Smith1952>Greig-Smith P (1952) The use of random and contiguous quadrats in the study of the structure of plant communities. Ann. Bot. 16:293-316</ref> who considered it to be
: <math> V_{ \theta } = \frac{ 2 } { n - 1 } </math>
For large samples these two formulae are in approximate agreement. This test is related to the later Katz's ''J''<sub>n</sub> statistic.
If the population obeys Taylor's law then
: <math> \theta = am^{ b - 1 } </math>
;Note
A refinement on this test has also been published<ref name=Gosset1986>Gosset E, Louis B (1986) The binning analysis - Towards a better significance test. Astrophysics Space Sci 120 (2) 263-306</ref> These authors noted that this test tends to detect overdispersion at higher scales even when this was not present in the data. They noted that the use of the multinomial distribution may be more appropriate than the use of a Poisson distribution for such data. The statistic ''θ'' is distributed
: <math> \theta = \frac{ s^2 }{ m } = \frac{ 1 } { n } \sum{ ( x_i - \frac{ n }{ N } )^2 } </math>
where ''N'' is the number of sample units, ''n'' is the total number of samples examined and ''x''<sub>i</sub> are the individual data values.
The expectation and variance of ''θ'' are
: <math> E( \theta ) = \frac{ N } { N - 1} </math>
: <math> Var( \theta ) = \frac{ ( N - 1 )^2 } { N^3 } - \frac { 2N - 3 } { nN^2 }</math>
For large ''N'' ''E''(θ) is approximately 1 and
: <math> Var( \theta ) \sim\ \frac{ 2 } { N } ( 1 - \frac{ 1 } { n } ) </math>
If the number of individuals sampled ( ''n'' ) is large this estimate of the variance is in agreement with those derived earlier. However, for smaller samples these latter estimates are more precise and should be used.
